Population aging and structural over/underinvestment
Intro:
The accumulation of long-term physical capital assets is one of the most volatile components of aggregate demand that strongly affects fluctuations in economic growth and employment (Crowley and Hallett 2014; Arestis and Sawyer 2005; Stockhammer et al. 2014). As shown in Feijo et al. (2016), Asada (2012), and Hall (1980), stabilization policies typically focus on the variation of the cyclical component of investment rate within the economic and financial cycle. Cyclical overinvestment results from an investment boom in the upper phase of the economic/financial cycle with significant effects on (among others) increasing sovereign default rate (Park 2017), intensifying international trade conflicts (Schnabl 2019), and factor markets distortions (Gu 2014). Cyclical underinvestment is typically a result of a deep financial crisis that leads to worsening lending conditions in countries with less developed financial sectors (Corneli 2009), causing a global savings glut and large current account imbalances in a globalized world. It is also a consequence of massive austerity measures applied by the government to prevent the country’s over-indebtedness (Christodoulakis and Axioglou 2017), which leads to deep disinvestments that have serious adverse effects on long-term growth and employment in the Eurozone. Besides cyclical over/underinvestment, some countries might deal with the significant suboptimal and unsustainable long-term speed of capital accumulation of a structural (cycle-adjusted) character. Structural over/underinvestment is represented by investments that are not in line with the structural characteristics of an economy relevant to the growth of productive capital assets (like total factor productivity, potential economic growth, the marginal product of capital, cost of capital, risk, and regulation). It is difficult to identify whether the country is structurally or cyclically over/underinvested (or both), making it difficult to distinguish between cyclically or structurally oriented policy measures that policy institutions must apply to restore the equilibrium. Restrictive/expansionary stabilization policy measures that work fine for the cyclical component typically do not work for the structural one that is more micro and institution-based (for a variety of causes and policy actions, see a role of government credit guarantee for underinvestment in Adhikary et al. (2021), an impact of improvement in accounting information comparability for investment efficiency reducing the extent of underinvestment in Yang et al. (2021) and underinvestment in higher education in the US and its consequences for optimal development and economic growth as in McMahon (2018)). Current research on macroeconomic structural over/underinvestment is rather limited. The research primarily focuses on the impact of a single structural factor on the suboptimal size of investments in a single country and not on the simultaneous effects of a set of structural factors in a panel of countries. The effect of expected technological progress that increases the productivity of future generation of capital assets as a reason for current underinvestment is analyzed in Feichtinger et al. (2006). Chou et al. (2018) show that despite fast capital accumulation in emerging and transition countries, the rate of return on invested capital does not decline, which means that these countries are still underinvested. Abel and Eberly (1999) show that irreversibility and uncertainty increase the cost of capital, leading to lower-than-optimal capital stock. Investors’ irrationality and uncertainty in investment decision-making might result in over/underinvestment, as shown in Driver and Temple (2012). Dalmazzo and Marini (2000) analyze political instability and insecure proper rights as a source of underinvestment. The impact of capital assets underinvestment and labor market over-employment on the effects of higher minimum wage on capital accumulation, wage distribution, and change of employment are modeled in Bauducco and Janiak (2018).
 Because a specific phase of the investment cycle does not significantly affect the current level of the capital-to-output ratio if it is not followed by long-term investment disequilibria (capital being defined as cumulative investments reduced by cumulative capital depreciation), we chose to set structural unsustainability condition based on both the rate of investment and the capital-to-output ratio. We consider the rate of investments as structurally unsustainable (suboptimal) if it significantly over/undershoots its equilibrium level and if, at the same time, existed capital-to-output ratio is significantly higher/lower than the equilibrium one. It allows us not to consider the economies, which are cyclically over/underinvested, but their capital-to-output ratio is in line with structural characteristics of the economy, structurally over/underinvested. It also allows us to focus on the countries that struggle with over/underinvestment and avoid the countries that face up short-term deviations of investment rate out of the equilibrium. An equilibrium rate of investment is usually estimated either by theoretical derivation from the steady-state condition of the Solow-Swan growth model or the Cobb–Douglas production function (Shioji and Khai 2012) or using implied equilibrium derived from the econometric model of investment using theoretically based structural factors (Lee et al. 2012). Applying a neoclassical growth model/production function to derive the equilibrium rate of investment is highly sensitive to a selection of the method determining the equilibrium values of capital, potential economic growth rate, and equilibrium growth rate of the total factor productivity. They are directly unobservable variables either estimated mechanically by applying different kinds of filters whose parameters are difficult to justify economically as consistent with the concept of equilibrium or set as specifically targeted values at a level of capital accumulation of a mature country the economies should converge to. The fact that economies vary significantly with their structural factors further complicates setting a country’s equilibrium investment rate. Finally, the Solow-Swan growth model and the Cobb–Douglas production function do not see the equilibrium capital accumulation as a part of the intertemporal optimization of consumption/savings of rational agents to differentiate between transitory and long-term disequilibria. Resulting combinations of equilibrium values of capital, potential economic growth, and growth of the total factor productivity produce a wide range of the equilibrium investments rate, making an analysis of structural over/underinvestment potentially very fragile. The implied equilibrium allows determining the equilibrium rate of investment as a time-variable country-specific equilibrium based on the deterministic part of an econometric model of capital accumulation estimated using the country’s structural characteristics as investment’s economic fundamentals on a large sample of countries. It allows us to consider the cross-country differences in their structural factors and their different inter-temporal preferences over the current and future consumption/speed of capital accumulation. To overcome an inherent conflict between the concept of equilibrium used in macroeconomics and the optimality used in microeconomics, we employ both macroeconomic and microeconomic structural factors of capital accumulation in deriving the implied equilibrium. The equilibrium rate of investment derived in a tradition of the Solow-Swan growth model and the Cobb–Douglas production function also does not take into account that capital goods are long-term assets that rational economic agents can accumulate more/less than it would correspond to the current equilibrium when they expect significant structural changes in the economy in the future. In this case, over/underinvestment may be a transitory phenomenon that does not require any cardinal changes in economic policies and behavior of economic agents because it is in line with the intertemporal optimum of the utility-maximizing rational economic agent in his consumption/savings/capital assets production decisions. While intertemporal optimization of consumption/savings becomes an inherent part of the intertemporal approach to current account balance (Razin 1993; Obstfeld and Rogoff 1995; Milesi-Ferretti and Razin 1996) that states the current account equilibrium to be given by sustainable time-variable relation of current consumption and future savings driven by time preferences of consumers, the speed of capital accumulation, that has the same effect on the current account as the formation of saving, is not typically considered within a framework of intertemporal optimization. From the perspectives of the intertemporal approach, capital accumulation assumes that the utility of using currently purchased long-term capital assets can be consumed not only today but also in the future when changing structural characteristics of the economy might change demand for capital assets and their production and when the price of capital assets and funding costs of capital accumulation might be higher/lower than in the current period. Therefore, utility optimization can lead rational agents to purchase capital assets today in expectation of future changes in structural factors of capital accumulation, price of capital assets, and cost of funding making capital accumulation more expensive. Demographic changes associated with a change in the population’s age, size, and structure result from changes in birth and death rates, life expectancy, size of the economically active population, frequency of single-person households, and changing migration intensity. d’Albis (2007) presents an OLG model to analyze the ambiguous effects of an exogenous shift in the birth rate capital-to-capita ratio. His conclusions are tested by Lau (2009), who confirms positive relation between population growth and capital accumulation but not in the case of industrial counties. Voigtländer and Voth (2006) show that a limitation of fertility is responsible for higher per capita incomes and industrialization during England's industrial revolution using the OLG model with endogenous retirement decisions Dedry et al. (2017) show that lower fertility and higher longevity affects the speed of accumulation differently based on a type of pension system (unregulated retirement age systems or mandatory retirement systems with defined contributions fare). Ludwig and Vogel (2010) find that changes in mortality and fertility, which increases population age, lead to more education that increases the relative return of human capital over the physical capital and, subsequently, their speed of accumulation. Demographic changes that increase the age of the population are expected to occur in many countries in the nearest decades (UN 2015, 2022), which naturally affects the speed of capital accumulation (see the impact of alternative scenarios of demographic changes on the dynamics of capital accumulation in the neoclassical growth model in Mierau and Turnovsky (2014)). Such complex changes in demographic factors influence equilibrium investment through a change in the growth rate of natural employment (Cai 2015; Barnichon and Figura 2016; Crary 2000; Krashevski 1988) and labor productivity (Choudhry et al. 2016; Guest 2011; Canning 2011; Guest and Swift 2008), an adaptation of equilibrium capital-to-output ratio (Chen, and Lin 2021; Stirati 2017; Gros 2014) and real interest rate (Papetti 2021; Sudo and Takizuka 2020; Carvalho et al. 2016; Ikeda and Saito 2014), or implicitly due to changes in the capital-to-labor ratio (Pessoa and Van Reenen 2014; Nguyen and Smith 2007; Miles 1999) and the ratio of labor costs to capital costs (Cullmann and Stiel 2022; De la Croix et al. 2013). Investments are also influenced by population aging, which initiates the structural transformation of the economic system. Siliverstovs et al. (2011) identify positive effects of aging on the share of employees in the community, social, personal, and financial services and negative effects on employment in agriculture, manufacturing, construction, and mining and quarrying industries. The conclusions are confirmed by Cravino et al. (2022), who show that population aging increases the size of the service sector, which is less capital-intensive. The effects of population aging on investments could be analyzed from a broader perspective as a consequence of changing volatility of main macroeconomic factors like in Guimaraes and Tiryaki (2020), who link an increasing age of the population and increasing output volatility due to changing labor market and international volatility while consumption and investment volatility are decreasing at the same time. Jäger and Schmidt (2016) find a long-term negative relationship between the share of elderly people and public investment rates in developed countries, assuming that old-age cohorts prefer a lower investment rate than middle-aged cohorts. As far as we know, no existing research analyzes the relationship between the phenomenon of over/underinvestment and population aging using a large panel of countries. Therefore, the article’s objective is to identify over/underinvested economies using the panel of 154 countries in 2005–2017 and to verify whether identified over/underinvestment is related to expected population aging measured by the United Nations’ prediction of old dependency ratio. We figure out the size of over/underinvestment and analyze the frequency of over/underinvested countries in the dataset based on changing horizon of demographic prediction. Next, the group of long-term and middle-term over/underinvested countries is identified. In order to test stability of the OLS estimations of the benchmark model, we provide four robustness checks: (a) benchmark model is estimated by the 2SLS to consider the potential impact of endogeneity on the OLS estimations, (b) the OLS and the 2SLS models with the alternative demographic variables related to population aging (death rate, birth rate, and life expectancy at birth) are estimated to consider the effects of demographic variable choice representing population aging; (c) the OLS and the 2SLS models using country’s institutional quality (Economic freedom index and its sub-parts like Investment freedom, Business freedom and Property rights indices, and Fragility index) are estimated to analyze the effects of using alternative proxies instead of risk premium, and transaction and administrative costs, and finally, (d) the size of over/underinvestment, the frequency of over/underinvested countries, and the group of long-term and middle-term over/underinvested countries is tested in order to analyze how they are sensitive to changes in the method of model estimation and usage of alternative demographic variables representing population aging. We find that the current rate of capital accumulation is determined by expected population aging measured by the old-age dependency ratio up to a relatively long period of 31 years. The estimations also indicate that the extent of overinvestment is distinctly larger than that of underinvestment. We present that a transition between the levels of over/underinvestment and disappearance of over/underinvestment does occur in times of insignificant cyclical component in investments. It is shown that the combination of the rate of investment model and capital-to-output ratio model results in a decrease in the frequency of structurally over/underinvested countries. Finally, we identified three structurally long-term overinvested economies and nine long-term underinvested economies, while four countries are medium-term overinvested and three countries are underinvested. The robustness checks show that all these results are not significantly influenced by the methods of estimations, choice of demographic variables representing population aging, and alternative country’s institutional quality characteristics. The article is organized as follows: Part 2 provides a short discussion on structural determinants of investment based on the macroeconomic concept of equilibrium investment and the microeconomic concept of optimal capital used in the production of the optimizing agent. The next part presents a review of the literature with a focus on demographic determinants of the investment rate. Parts 4 and 5 describe data used in empirical analysis and clarify in detail the form and method of estimating the econometric model of implied equilibrium. Part 6 presents the results of the estimation and provides their interpretation. The final part comes up with conclusions.

Title: A sectoral specification of Okun’s law in oil-producing countries: evidence from panel ARDL model
Intro: In 1962, Arthur Okun introduced the relationship between the unemployment rate and output growth using US economic data. Since then, this relationship has been known as “Okun’s law.” Accordingly, unemployment and output are inversely related according to Okun’s law, that is, a 3 percent increase in output growth causes the unemployment rate to decline by 1 percent. Different studies pointed out that the estimated Okun’s coefficients may vary from 3 percent, as indicated in Okun (1962). Several studies have been conducted on Okun’s relationship and its stability. For instance, Knotek (2007) stated the instability of Okun’s law. In contrast, Ball et al. (2019) asserted the stability and validity of Okun’s relationships across countries. Furthermore, there might be a new aspect that drives the instability of Okun’s law. In this respect, many recent studies have introduced a sectoral approach to Okun’s relationship. These studies have considered the different responses of the unemployment rate to output growth in different economic sectors (Apap and Gravino 2017; Dimian et al. 2018; Goto and Bürgi 2020). Oil-producing countries' main economic characteristic is the substantial share of oil revenues over the total GDP that is at the same time a major source of government revenues. As a consequence, oil rents are considered as a key driver of economic growth in many oil-rich countries where the output share of the competent economic sectors, such as agriculture, industry, and services, displays reduced contribution over GDP and affects less economic growth. The oil sector leaves limited resources to the development of other non-oil sectors (Matallah 2020) within these economies. Hence, the varying sectoral behavior across countries may drive the cross-country differences in Okun's law at the aggregate and disaggregated levels. Furthermore, the theoretical and empirical studies by Amiri et al. (2019) and Corden and Neary (1982) indicated evident resource dependence of economic output as well as employment and unemployment levels in the competent sectors within an economy across oil-producing countries. Based on these findings, we can assume in our approach that oil rents as a crucial resource may drive the output and unemployment level of the competent economic sectors and to fluctuate differently over the business cycles, producing different Okun’s coefficients at the sectoral level. In this short study, we re-examine this issue by analyzing the magnitude of Okun’s coefficient at the sectoral level. We investigate the sectoral approach of Okun’s law as it relates to oil dependency. The innovation of this paper over the previous studies is the focus on “sectoral” rather than the “aggregate” Okun’s coefficient. Normally, the aggregate level of Okun’s law is examined since unemployment refers to the whole economy. However, with the view presented above, it is more meaningful to test and explore whether oil rents weaken other economic sectors and affect unemployment in resource-rich countries. Besides, this paper makes a novel contribution to the literature that studied the sectoral specification of Okun’s law, such as Apap and Gravino (2017) and Goto and Bürgi (2020). We explore the response of unemployment to different sectors’ output growth using the sectoral version of Okun’s law in the context of oil-producing countries. In this respect, countries highly dependent on oil incomes from those less dependent on such revenues are differentiated. In contrast to the above studies, our analysis includes the impact of the interaction term between oil rents and sectoral output growth to explore whether oil rents cause a different response or sensitivity of unemployment to the sectoral output changes. It is essential to understand whether the oil sector’s output succeeded in achieving sustainable economic growth and, therefore, a low unemployment rate, in other words, escaping the so-called resource curse. In this study, we consider the role of oil dependence on the responsiveness of unemployment to output growth in the manufacturing, agriculture, and service sectors by employing a panel ARDL model for 17 oil-producing countries from 2000 to 2019. Countries where oil rents contribute highly to the total GDP are chosen in the current analysis. Following Groce (2020) and Markowitz et al. (2020), oil-producing countries were defined as if oil rents account for at least 10% of GDP. By linking the oil dependence to the sectoral approach of Okun’s law, we are able to examine whether the so-called resource curse phenomenon affects the performance of the economic sectors and unemployment rates. To answer the research question, we include the interaction term in the analysis to explore whether oil rents weaken the other sectors in resource-rich countries. Since the emphasis on long-run relationships becomes a significant part of macroeconomic modeling, modern macroeconomic modeling becomes more dynamic and employs lag variables as part of panel data analysis. Thus, the current paper applied the CS-ARDL and PMG estimators to investigate the possible association between the unemployment rate and sectoral output growth in the long and short runs. The rest of the study is structured as follows. Section 2 briefly discusses the literature review and the relevant studies. The empirical methodology and data are introduced in Sect. 3. Section 4 presents the empirical results containing the baseline and the extensions analysis. Lastly, Sect. 5 concludes.

Financing and returns of Shari’ah-compliant contracts and sustainable investing in the Islamic banking of Oman
Intro: The global Islamic finance industry has grown significantly in recent years in response to the market fluctuations caused by the COVID-19 pandemic (Fakhrunnas and Ramly 2017). Simultaneously, Islamic countries have become more concerned about how ethical and social consumption factors affect Islamic finance (Ahmad et al. 2018). By its nature, Islamic finance addresses sustainability and accountability. Therefore, the rules of governance were taken into account to expand the sustainable base, which has been proven in COVID-19 from a commercial point of view (Awan et al. 2011). The solid foundation of the Islamic economy, which is based on the importance of the global economy, has led to an increased demand for products and services based on Islamic law. Islamic finance helps create value for consumers and achieve global social welfare through social awareness (Ahmad et al. 2018). According to the Islamic Financial Services Industry Stability Report (IFSISR, 2020), global Islamic assets grew by 7.8% from 2014 to 2019 due to a consistent approach to Islamic finance and strong investments in infrastructure, sukuk, and Islamic funds. Global Islamic financial assets grew by 14.4% year-on-year to reach $2,875 billion in 2019, representing a 2% increase from 2018; this growth was the result of electronic transactions for financial products and services. Sukuk increased by 14.5% year-on-year to reach $538 billion in 2018 (IFSISR 2020). Iran and Saudi Arabia have a strong focus on Islamic assets, which represented 66% of total assets in 2019 in both countries. Bahrain has the highest percentage of Islamic financing assets as a percentage of GDP (124%) followed by Malaysia (53%), Iran (47%), Kuwait (43%) and Qatar (40%) (IFSISR, 2020). Islamic bank's number has increased, creating a competitive market with commercial banks in many Islamic countries where high-quality services are provided (Fakhrunnas and Ramly 2017). Muslim population increases in the Middle East and North Africa and South Asia have led to an increase in the number of banking services that are compliant with Islamic law in those regions (Fiador and Sarpong-Kumankoma 2020). Although compliance with Shari’ah is the basis of every Islamic banking institution, there are differences in the application of Shari’ah views in different countries and regions, especially between the Middle East and Malaysia. Most central banks and financial institutions have recently started to adopt Islamic accounting and auditing standards. The Islamic banking industry is considered the largest sector in the Islamic industry, with around 69.3% of the industry’s assets in 2019 (IFSISR, 2020). However, the total share of Islamic banking services decreased by 73% in 2014 due to the increased use of Sukuk and Islamic funds as Islamic capital market instruments, with a growth of 7% during the past five years. The Islamic banking sector began to grow in 2016 and rose by 14% in 2019 to reach $2 billion in global assets (IFSISR, 2020). This growth can be Rochet explained by improvements in the assets of the Gulf Cooperation Council (GCC) countries, which witnessed the merger of many Islamic banks to enhance competitiveness, attract stable deposits, and improve banking efficiency. Globally, the GCC countries account for 45.2% of total Islamic banking assets (IFSISR 2020). Saudi Arabia (USD 551.1 billion) leads the GCC in terms of Islamic banking assets, followed by the UAE (USD 162.7 billion), Kuwait (USD 127.1 billion), and Qatar (USD 121.7 billion). Saudi Arabia recorded a double-digit growth rate in Islamic assets in 2020, while Kuwait, Oman, and Qatar remained stable amid adverse economic fluctuations due to the COVID-19 pandemic (IFSISR, 2020). Islamic banks play an important role in the sustainability of Islamic finance in Oman by enhancing their commitment to sustainable economic growth and promoting an inclusive financial and economic system. This role is in line with many of Oman Vision 2040’s principles, such as financial sector stability, economic growth, reduced poverty, wealth distribution, and financial and social inclusion. Islamic financial institutions help customers by integrating environmental, social, and governance (ESG) criteria into their businesses and financing activities to achieve the UN Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). By engaging in strategic collaborations on banking supervision, technology adoption, accounting, and audit standards, Islamic banks have minimised the key legal and Shari’ah governance-related challenges faced by Islamic banks and accelerated financial deepening and inclusion in Oman. Islamic banking was adopted in Oman at the end of 2012 earning huge profits and enjoying a high asset quality rating, which enabled competition with traditional banks. By the end of 2020, more than 80 Islamic bank branches and Islamic banking windows were offering services using finance tools (Central Bank of Oman 2022). The main Islamic banks were Bank Nizwa and Alizz Islamic Bank, and traditional banks operated six Islamic banking windows. The growth trend of Islamic banking increased by 11.6% in 2021, and the market share of Islamic banks and Islamic banking windows increased from 14.3% at the end of 2020 to 15.2% at the end of 2021, representing OMR 5.9 billion in total assets. The financing for Islamic banking mostly came from government and public enterprise projects, which reflect the fastest-growing in the GCC regarding Shari’ah-compliant banking services in GCC countries. Although Shari’ah-compliant banking services have a positive trajectory in the short to medium term, there are many challenges. However, the Oman Banks Association’s awareness of Islamic tools, favorable legislation, and fair and ethical practices has created a strong demand for Islamic services. According to the Central Bank of Oman (2022), the total assets of Oman Islamic banks and Islamic banking windows increased by 10.7% in 2021 to reach OMR 6 billion in 2022. Oman’s Islamic banking assets accounted for 15.4% of overall banking sector assets in 2022. Moreover, Islamic banking has boosted financial inclusivity, accelerated economic development, and increased investment stability. In Oman, despite an increase in the number of changes to the economic market, regulatory improvements and market maturity enhancements were evident in 2019 and 2020. Meanwhile, the annual growth slowed to 6% in 2020 from 11% in 2019 (IFSISR, 2020). Islamic banking continued to rise in Oman in the last three years, which was rated in 2020 as the second fastest-growing Islamic finance market in the world by Moody’s (IFSISR, 2020). Oman recorded an annual deposit growth rate of 6% in 2020, which was slower than the 2019 rate of 10% and was attributed to a drop in oil prices. Islamic bank deposits amounted to nearly four million Omani riyals, and their share of the total rose to 14% in 2020, compared to 13% in 2018 (IFSISR, 2020). Islamic finance in Oman reached 16% of total financing in 2020, with a growth rate of 9% in 2020 to reach four million Omani riyals as a result of the increasing demand for Islamic products and support from Islamic windows in traditional banks that offer Islamic products (IFSISR, 2020). The Central Bank of Oman issued a financial technology protection fund in 2020 to enhance the environment for Islamic financial entrepreneurs by providing guidance and access to investors. In that same year, Oman launched the first online Takaful platform, through which eight companies provide insurance coverage, including travel and property insurance. In recent years, Islamic finance has emerged and become associated with the traditional banking system. Islamic financial activities must be compatible with Shari’ah (Wilson 2009; Hassan, 2010; Grassa 2013), and Shari’ah governance has emerged in many countries as an important framework that supports sustainability and the needs of Islamic financial institutions. However, the absence of a unified comprehensive Shari’ah governance framework impedes global financial development. Shari’ah governance is a specific characteristic of corporate governance in the financial structure that concerns the religious aspects of the activities and conduct of Islamic financial institutions (IFIs) (Hasan 2010). According to Standard 10 of the Islamic Financial Services Board (IFSB), a Shari’ah governance system refers to regulatory arrangements and legislation that have been created to ensure that international financial institutions respond to and comply with Shari’ah as well as their own internal provisions (IFSISR, 2020). According to Principle 3.1 of the IFSB Guiding Principles on Corporate Governance, the best mechanism should be adopted to ensure compliance with the Shari’ah principles of tawhid (the Oneness of Allah), the shura process (consultation), property rights and contractual obligations. Iqbal and Mirakhor (2004) indicated that, from an Islamic perspective, governance refers to Shari’ah governance, which covers overall governance issues as well as the protection of stakeholders’ rights, meaning in the past only stakeholder models were used to explore governance issues. The sustainability features of financing projects can be evaluated by comparing the international financing methods and sustainability practices used in different sectors and determining whether the financial policy establishes a framework to harmonise environmental issues, society, and financial sector governance (Kammer et al. 2015; Zawawi et al. 2014). The role of Islamic finance can be determined by participating in the development of infrastructure within private sources (Campisi et al. 2017). Furthermore, the Islamic financial sector was included in the fiscal policy of governments to diversify the sector and enhance its resilience against negative shocks (Abbes and Trichilli 2015; Saiti et al. 2014). Islamic finance is based on profit and loss sharing (PLS) and avoids risk as much as possible to prevent usury (Diaw 2015). Financing tools, including interest-free loans, are used to achieve real assets that provide a reasonable and fair reward for investment in the form of a fixed share, which is linked to the real economy and is not just a tool for recovering liquidity (Campisi et al. 2017). Song and Oosthuizen (2014) and López Mejía et al. (2014) argued that Islamic banks are less likely to withdraw deposits and are more stable than commercial banks; however, they noted that banking systems may differ significantly from country to country based on the policies of their banks. To measure sustainable investing, the present study used variables that were likely to have the greatest impact on the financing and returns of Shari’ah-compliant products and services: capital adequacy, risk sensitivity, and asset quality. Most studies have focused on the traditional motivations for opening Islamic banks, namely, increased profit and economic and social development. The present study employed a broader focus by examining several factors that influence the adoption of Islamic banking. The first factor was religious motivation, which influences customer behavior. The second factor, which also affects customer behaviour, concerns the quality of service and brand awareness. These attributes play key roles in Islamic products, which are all based on Shari’ah compliance. The third factor, sustainable investing, is strongly supported by Oman Vision 2040, which states that Islamic banks should promote financial stability and economic growth, reduce poverty, wealth distribution, and financial and social inclusion. The present study aimed to examine the financing and returns of Shari’ah-compliant contracts and sustainable investing in Islamic banking in Oman over quarterly periods from 2014 to 2020. Islamic financing instruments were evaluated based on three pillars: murābahah, ijārah muntahia bittamlīk, and wakālah. Murabaha represents a sales contract that is owned by a buyer at the request of a debtor and sold at a deferred price over time and at the cost of purchase plus price margins. jārah muntahia bittamlīk refers to a contract between a debtor and a creditor in which the latter buys an asset at a specified price and then rents it to the borrower for a monthly amount and receives remuneration by charging periodic fees for the leased asset. At the end of the contract, the debtor obtains ownership of the asset. In a wakālah transaction, the main account holder appoints an Islamic financing institution (agent) to carry out investment activities on his/her behalf in order to recycle liquidity in the short term within the terms of the Islamic banking system. This study also aimed to fill a research gap that emerged based on the importance of the Islamic economy in normal economic conditions and repeated financial crises over the past few decades. Over the past four decades, the Islamic economy has awoken from a stage of deep slumber, prompting a deep in economic analyses. However, the literature still needs more research on the role of Islamic finance and returns in supporting sustainable governance. This study offers four main contributions to the literature. First, to the best of our knowledge, this is one of few studies to analyse the returns of Shari’ah-compliant contracts through three proxies: the total financing and returns of murābahah, ijārah muntahia bittamlīk and wakālah Islamic banking tools. Second, this study shows the importance of investing in the sustainability of Shari’ah governance and the importance of Islamic banking. Third, the geographic location of Oman and its stable regulations have led Oman to have a high percentage of oil rents compared to other GCC countries and the rest of the world which raises the novelty of this study. Finally, the autoregressive distributive lag model (ARDL) technique and the error correction model (ECM) were applied to examine the relationship between the financing and returns of Shari’ah-compliant contracts and sustainable investing measured by Shari’ah governance. The main research question was as follows: Do the financing and returns of Shari’ah-compliant contracts promote sustainable investing in the Islamic banking system of Oman? The study findings should capture the attention of policymakers and help them rethink funding techniques, extend their analysis to different cultural and financial models, and recognise the importance of Islamic financing tools for sustainable investments based on Shari’ah governance. The findings can also drive the future application of alternative financing instruments that are able to minimise the cost of funds and sustain investments and are devoted to the reduction of risk and its negative effects on sustainability investments. This paper is organised into five sections. Section 1 presents the introduction and motivation for this research. Section 2 describes the literature review framework. Section 3 describes the methodology and econometric models used in the study. Section 4 presents the results. Section 5 contains a discussion of the results. Finally, Sect. 6 includes the conclusion, policy implications, and recommendations for future research.

Remittances, economic complexity, and new firms’ creation: empirical evidence from a large sample of countries
Intro: International migration is a multifaceted phenomenon that includes forming large communities of people living abroad, resulting in diasporas. These diasporas significantly affect their countries of origin, including their social, political, and economic environments, as discussed by social scientists. Economists have investigated how diasporas impact the economy of the origin countries, particularly in terms of economic development (Bahar 2020). One of the most hotly debated issues is the role of remittances, with two opposing views: an optimistic one that sees positive effects and a pessimistic one that denies them (Clemens and McKenzie 2018; Naudé et al. 2017; Yang 2011). One less explored issue regarding the role of remittances in the economy is their impact on creating new firms. This paper aims to address this gap and examine whether the economic complexity of a country is relevant for understanding the impact of remittances on new firm creation. Our research is framed around three key points. Firstly, in the last few decades, remittances have grown exponentially from $122 million in 2000 to $706 million in 2020, representing a more than fivefold increase (Fig. 1) (World Bank 2021). In many countries, remittances have become the primary financial flow, surpassing foreign direct investment and official development assistance flows. Furthermore, a significant portion of international remittances is transmitted through informal channels and goes unrecorded in official statistics.Footnote 1 The growing importance of remittances for investment purposes has drawn the attention of scholars in various fields, such as economics, management, entrepreneurship, and international development agencies (Ratha 2003, 2007). Although remittances are primarily used for non-investment purposes, such as food, housing, and education, they have been shown to stimulate new investments as a source of financial funds. In fact, many studies have suggested that remittances play a potentially positive role in new business creation. Single-country (e.g., Kiliç et al. 2009; Woodruff and Zenteno 2007) and cross-country studies (e.g., Cummings et al. 2021; Yavuz and Bahadir 2022) have found a positive correlation between remittances and new business activities. These studies hypothesize that remittances increase entrepreneurial activities by providing financial resources for new investments. Migrant remittance inflows (US$ million) Source: World Bank Secondly, new firms generate more employment than larger incumbent firms (Haltiwanger 2015), and this explains why policymakers try to design policy incentives to promote entrepreneurship (Ratinho et al. 2020). However, in many countries, particularly low-income ones, there is a lack of capital needed to start new firms. If remittances from migrants can provide an alternative and additional source of funding for new businesses, it could significantly benefit the economic and social well-being of these countries. Thirdly, it is surprising that the connection between economic complexity and entrepreneurship has received little attention in the literature. According to Nguyen et al. (2021), existing empirical studies on the determinants of entrepreneurship tend to adopt either a micro- or macro-perspective, occasionally exploring the impact of government efficiency and institutional quality. However, they overlook the crucial role of the economy’s structure in entrepreneurship. In a recent survey, Ratinho et al. (2020) suggest that future research should investigate the relationship between economic structure and entrepreneurship. In this paper, we make several contributions to the literature. Firstly, we show that the impact of real per capita remittances (REM) on new firm creation is inversely mediated by economic complexity. Since economic complexity is positively correlated with economic development, remittances are more likely to facilitate the establishment of new firms in less developed economies rather than in more advanced ones. Secondly, our sub-sample analysis for high and upper-middle-income (HUMI) countries on the one hand and low- and lower-middle-income (LLMI) countries on the other corroborates our hypothesis regarding the positive impact of REM on new limited liability company (NLLC) creation in LLMI countries and the negative impact in HUMI countries. Furthermore, in both sub-samples the economic complexity index (ECI) negatively mediates the impact of REM on NLLC. Thirdly, the sub-sample analysis at the regional level (Africa, Asia, Europe, Latin America and the Caribbean) reveals that in Africa, the average marginal effect of REM on NLLC creation is negative, despite increasing as ECI grows. In Asia, the average marginal effect of REM on NLLC creation is positive and decreases as ECI increases. In Europe, we do not find any positive or negative role, whereas, in Latin American and the Caribbean countries, we observe a consistently positive average marginal effect of REM on NLLC creation, which increases as ECI increases. Fourthly, based on our empirical results, we present and discuss some policy implications. Our findings suggest that economic policies should be tailored to the specific needs of each country to address the challenges they face. Policy initiatives such as reducing informality, improving competition, lowering remittance transfer costs, and introducing a special legal status for new firms created through remittances would facilitate the channelling of remittances toward new business creation. Additionally, institutions in origin countries should encourage the creation of diaspora networks to increase awareness of new business opportunities in their respective countries of origin. Due to data availability constraints, we examine 78 countries from 2006 to 2020 in our empirical analysis, and we use a negative binomial regression model to estimate the relationship between remittances, economic complexity, and new firm creation. This estimation strategy is suitable because our dependent variable is an over-dispersed count variable. The remainder of the paper is structured as follows. In the next section, we review the relevant literature. Section 3 provides a detailed account of our empirical investigation, and Sect. 4 presents our results. Policy implications are discussed in Sect. 5, and the paper concludes with Sect. 6.

Clean versus dirty electricity generation and economic growth in South Africa: time–frequency study
Intro: Electricity is vital for economic activity as well as everyday living and is thus considered a crucial component of an economy’s development process. It is well known that economies with high (low) levels of electricity production and consumption tend to have higher (lower) levels of economic growth and development (Akinbami et al 2021). Therefore, access to electricity is one of the most crucial services governments can provide for improving the standard of living for poor people (Mahfouh and Amar 2014). The global urgency to increase peoples access and use of electricity is re-iterated in the sustainable development goal (SDG) 7 which seeks to “…ensure access to affordable, reliable, sustainable and modern energy for all…”. Over the last few decades there have been growing concerns over the worlds dependency on coal for generating most of the world’s electricity. The green-house gas emissions (GHG) and the non-renewability associated with the use of ‘dirty energy’ have prompted a global movement towards a ‘cleaner and greener’ world. Renewable energies are considered the ideal energy source for addressing the ‘twin global energy’ problems of poorer countries lacking access to electricity and richer countries with electricity access using dirty sources (International Energy Agency 2022). For instance, renewables have been argued to be more energy resilient compared to dirty energy sources and present technological advantages which can overcome problems of power outages (Anderson et al. 2018). Moreover, renewable energies have been advocated to have less harmful health effects on populations compared to non-renewable sources which are often associated with respiratory infections such as tuberculosis, low birthweight, cardiovascular problems, eye infections—all which lead to increased health expenses and reduced labour productivity (Rahut et al. 2017; Sahoo et al. 2022). However, renewables are also notorious for being high-priced and high-maintenance (Li et al. 2019). Furthermore, the slow response of developing economies towards adopting renewables and the current low usage of renewables may not be sufficient to impact long-run economic growth. Ultimately, the importance of developing countries transitioning into cleaner electricity production cannot be ignored and an important policy question is whether renewable electricity production can support socio-economic development in these countries. Amongst SSA countries, South Africa has attracted the most empirical attention on the (non)renewables-growth relationship and researchers consider the country an ideal case study for a variety of reasons. For instance, Ziramba (2008, 2009, 2015), Odhiambo (2009, 2010) and Akinbami et al. (2021) all find interest in South Africa as the largest producer, consumer and exporter of electricity in Africa which implies that any developments in the country’s domestic energy sector are most likely to spillover to many countries in the continent. Other authors highlight the country’s status as the largest emitter of carbon emissions in the Sub-Saharan African (SSA) and being amongst the top emitters in the world (Bah and Azam 2017, Akadiri et al. 2019; Bekun et al. 2019; Magazzino et al., 2021) whereas a few others highlight the country’s potential for creating clean energy such as boasting the only nuclear plant in Africa (Phiri and Nyoni 2016), being the only African country with coastal regions on both the Indian and Atlantic sides of the Oceans which gives the country a greater advantage in creating wind power (Akinbami et al. 2021) and also having abundant agricultural residual and sunshine levels for solar and biomass power generation, respectively (Ziramba 2009, 2013; Ayamolowo and Kusakana 2022). Nonetheless, the current empirical evidence on the impacts of renewable and non-renewable energy usage on economic growth for South Africa is inconclusive with some studies finding a positive impact of (non)renewables on growth (Akinboade et al. 2008; Ziramba 2013; Phiri and Nyoni 2016; Khobai and Le Roux 2018; Nyoni and Phiri (2020);;;;) whilst other studies find insignificant (Bhattacharya et al. 2016; Destek and Aslan 2017) or negative relationships (Shakouri and Yazdi 2017). Most notable these previous studies tend to use conventional cointegration models such as the FMOLS, DOLS, ARDL, VECM and granger causality tests, all which assume a linear relationship between the variables and are sensitivity to the choice of time period used for the analysis. Only a few studies employ nonlinear techniques such as the N-ARDL model and nonlinear granger causality tests which permit the researcher to evaluate certain forms of asymmetric whilst ignoring others. Our study proposes the use of more rigorous analytical tools which can capture various forms of asymmetries and whose results are not sensitivity to the choice of time period. Our study makes use of the continuous wavelet coherence methods to investigate the time–frequency relationship between renewable/non-renewable electricity production and economic growth in South Africa. Wavelets are mathematical tools which decompose a time series into different scales and thus localizes the signal in time–frequency space. This differs from econometric techniques which can only localize a series across a time (i.e. time series analysis) or a frequency plane (i.e. Fourier transforms) but not across both. The wavelet transforms of a time series can be envisioned in a three-dimensional plane consisting of time, real part and the imaginary/complex part from which the extracted amplitude and phase dynamics allows one to model the synchronization between a pair of variables in time–frequency space. The time–frequency synchronization of the series allows one to examine the co-movement between a pair of time series across 5 dimensions, namely; (i) a time-varying dimension (ii) frequency-varying dimension (iii) strength-varying dimension (iv) in-phase (positive co-movement) or anti-phase (negative co-movement) dimension (v) led-lag (causality) dimension. And whilst we acknowledge a growing number of empirical papers in the literature which use wavelet coherence analysis in energy studies (i.e. Mutascu (2018) for CO2 emissions and trade; Mata (2020) for electricity consumption and financial development; Magazzino et al. (2021) for energy and growth; Adebayo et al. (2022) for carbon emissions on economic growth, renewable energy, technological innovation and trade openness), our study is the first to make an application to the (non)renewable electricity – growth relationship. Our study uses wavelet coherence analysis to simultaneously address four empirical issues on the electricity-growth nexus, the first concerning the sign of the relationship, the second pertaining to the direction of causality between the variables, the third to whether the observed relationships are short-run or long-run, and the fourth to whether there exist time-varying and cyclical-varying asymmetries in the observed relationships. We further disaggregate electricity generation into dirty and clean sources for comparative purposes and use the findings to inform policymakers and other stakeholders if there are any economic benefits of phasing out coal in the electricity generation sector and including/increasing green energy sources on ESKOMs electricity grid. Altogether, our study presents new stylized facts on the relationship between ‘clean’ versus ‘dirty’ electricity production debate in South Africa and our findings have direct implications for the country’s electricity provider, ESKOM, who have been facing worsening ‘electricity outages’ caused by ‘breakdowns’ in local coal-based power stations. In this context, an important policy question which our study addresses is whether a shift from non-renewables to renewables electricity usage can simultaneously circumvent the load shedding problem and support long-run economic growth in an environmentally friendly manner. Moreover, our disaggregated analysis allows us to determine which source of clean electricity production is most sustainable for long-run growth and which sources need to be further developed to a level required to support such growth. The rest of the study is structured as follows. The next section of the paper presents the literature review. Section 3 presents the data and methods whilst Sect. 4 presents the empirical analysis. Section 5 presents further discussions of the results by comparing the results with previous literature providing policy implications whilst the study is concluded in Sect. 6.
